docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. ECONOMY Whoa, Big Fella! Two economic indicators released early last week suggested that the economy was throttling back from the heated pace it reached earlier this year. Sales of previously owned homes fell in April, while consumer confidence edged lower this month. Existing-home sales in the United States declined 2.5 percent last month, to an annual rate of 4.77 million units, according to the National Association of Realtors. And the Conference Board said its measure of consumer confidence declined to 135.2 in May, from 137.2 a month ago. A few days later, however, the Commerce Department reported that the economy in the first quarter was even stronger than initially reported. The gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of 4.8 percent, up from the earlier estimate of 4.2 percent. Not to be outdone by upbeat assessments, President Clinton said he now expected the budget surplus for 1998 to hit $39 billion.

docs.lead_paragraph: Since January, when accusations of an affair with a former intern were first leveled against President Clinton, the White House has cultivated an Olympian aura of imperviousness to the ensuing bombardment of questions, bawdy televised jokes and widely publicized prosecutorial suspicions. ''It hasn't distracted the President,'' said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, in an unusually sweeping appraisal on March 9. Mr. Clinton's aides have repeatedly argued that the President has been able to ''compartmentalize'' the charges and focus on the nation's business.

headline.main: Aides Differ on Toll That Starr Inquiry Has on Clinton
headline.kicker: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE PRESIDENT

docs.abstract: White House has for months cultivated air of Olympian imperviousness to frenzied inquiries into Pres Clinton and former aide Monica Lewinsky; spokesman Michael McCurry and other aides insist Clinton is not distracted, even as President's lawyers try to make legal case that Kenneth Starr's investigation has substantial impact on his ability to discharge his public obligations (S)
